articles.headline: Virus Exposes Weak Links in Peru’s Success Story
articles.snippet: Deep-rooted inequality and graft have thwarted the steps Peru took to prepare for its response to the pandemic.
articles.abstract: Deep-rooted inequality and graft have thwarted the steps Peru took to prepare for its response to the pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: LIMA, Peru — President Martín Vizcarra followed the best advice when the coronavirus arrived in Peru.
articles.byline: By Mitra Taj and Anatoly Kurmanaev

articles.headline: The Economy Is Reeling. The Tech Giants Spy Opportunity.
articles.snippet: Many companies are retreating. But Amazon, Apple, Facebook, Google and Microsoft are placing bets to get even bigger.
articles.abstract: Many companies are retreating. But Amazon, Apple, Facebook, Google and Microsoft are placing bets to get even bigger.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Even as Facebook grappled this month with an internal revolt and a cascade of criticism over its refusal to take action on President Trump’s inflammatory posts, the social network was actively making other bets behind the scenes.

articles.headline: Too Close for Comfort, and the Virus, in Russia’s Communal Apartments
articles.snippet: Riding out a virus lockdown in an apartment shared with 20 or so other people is about as unpleasant as it would seem. Along with the virus, “a silent paranoia” spreads.
articles.abstract: Riding out a virus lockdown in an apartment shared with 20 or so other people is about as unpleasant as it would seem. Along with the virus, “a silent paranoia” spreads.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — Through the thin wall separating her from her neighbors, Dr. Anzhela Kirilova began to hear the rasping cough associated with Covid-19 sometime in May. That was hardly a surprise, as a few weeks earlier her neighbors had heard the same cough coming from her room.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer and Sergey Ponomarev

articles.headline: Rage and Promises Followed Ferguson, but Little Changed
articles.snippet: Millions of dollars were spent to alter overly aggressive policing after the killing of Michael Brown in 2014, with little result. Will George Floyd’s death be different?
articles.abstract: Millions of dollars were spent to alter overly aggressive policing after the killing of Michael Brown in 2014, with little result. Will George Floyd’s death be different?
articles.lead_paragraph: America has been here before: a black man on the asphalt dying at the hands of the police. Convulsive protests across the country. A national reckoning. Vows to change.
articles.byline: By Shaila Dewan and Mike Baker

articles.headline: From Cosmetics to NASCAR, Calls for Racial Justice Are Spreading
articles.snippet: What started as a renewed push for police reform has now touched seemingly every aspect of American life.
articles.abstract: What started as a renewed push for police reform has now touched seemingly every aspect of American life.
articles.lead_paragraph: The reckonings have been swift and dizzying.
articles.byline: By Amy Harmon, Apoorva Mandavilli, Sapna Maheshwari and Jodi Kantor

articles.headline: Atlanta Police Chief Resigns After Officer Shoots and Kills a Black Man
articles.snippet: Rayshard Brooks had fallen asleep in his vehicle at a Wendy’s drive-through. He was shot after grabbing a Taser from an officer, the authorities said, prompting fresh unrest in the city.
articles.abstract: Rayshard Brooks had fallen asleep in his vehicle at a Wendy’s drive-through. He was shot after grabbing a Taser from an officer, the authorities said, prompting fresh unrest in the city.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Less than 24 hours after a white police officer shot and killed an African-American man outside a fast-food restaurant, Mayor Keisha Lance Bottoms of Atlanta announced on Saturday that the city’s police chief had resigned.
articles.byline: By Richard Fausset, Johnny Diaz and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs

articles.headline: A Reckoning at Condé Nast
articles.snippet: “It’s hard to be a person of color at this company,” a staff member said. In response to an uprising, Anna Wintour and the chief executive, Roger Lynch, offered apologies.
articles.abstract: “It’s hard to be a person of color at this company,” a staff member said. In response to an uprising, Anna Wintour and the chief executive, Roger Lynch, offered apologies.
articles.lead_paragraph: This was supposed to be Condé Nast’s year.

articles.headline: Coronavirus Cases Spike Across Sun Belt as Economy Lurches into Motion
articles.snippet: Arizona, Texas and Florida are reporting their highest case numbers yet. As of Saturday, coronavirus cases were climbing in 22 states amid reopenings.
articles.abstract: Arizona, Texas and Florida are reporting their highest case numbers yet. As of Saturday, coronavirus cases were climbing in 22 states amid reopenings.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The warning has echoed ominously for weeks from epidemiologists, small-town mayors and county health officials: Once states begin to reopen, a surge in coronavirus cases will follow.
articles.byline: By Julie Bosman and Mitch Smith

articles.headline: Chris Wallace, Insider and Outlier at Fox News
articles.snippet: The “Fox News Sunday” anchor opens up about his childhood, career and what he makes of his pro-Trump colleagues.
articles.abstract: The “Fox News Sunday” anchor opens up about his childhood, career and what he makes of his pro-Trump colleagues.
articles.lead_paragraph: Chris Wallace is a registered Democrat who hosts “Fox News Sunday,” a child of two Jews who keeps a rosary by his bedside, a Washington wonk who has vacationed in Italy with George Clooney.

articles.headline: Trading Sportsbooks for Brokerages, Bored Bettors Wager on Stocks
articles.snippet: When Russian table tennis or Korean baseball won’t scratch the itch, some are trying their hand at trading equities. It’s enough to move the market, analysts say.
articles.abstract: When Russian table tennis or Korean baseball won’t scratch the itch, some are trying their hand at trading equities. It’s enough to move the market, analysts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: When he wasn’t coaching sports, he was playing them or watching them. And if he was watching — well, a little skin in the game always made it more interesting for Steven Young, a teacher outside Philadelphia. Just small-dollar bets, mixed in with shuffling the rosters of his fantasy teams.

articles.headline: Newsrooms Are in Revolt. The Bosses Are in Their Country Houses.
articles.snippet: Those who can afford it left the city, shining a spotlight on class divisions in the media.
articles.abstract: Those who can afford it left the city, shining a spotlight on class divisions in the media.
articles.lead_paragraph: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y. — Real estate out here is too expensive for a working person, so the East Hampton Golf Club usually provides shared houses for its caddies. But Covid-19 means no boardinghouses, and no boarding means no caddies, and no caddies means that the media moguls who pay more than $400,000 to join (putting it in the middle range for initiation fees in the Hamptons) now must pull their own clubs around, which they’ve been telling one another reminds them of their youth, and which is just the kind of sacrifice that the coronavirus has brought to East Hampton.

articles.headline: Maria Ressa, Crusading Journalist, Is Convicted in Philippines Libel Case
articles.snippet: The conviction of Ms. Ressa, a critic of President Rodrigo Duterte and his violent drug war, is the latest blow to press freedoms in the country.
articles.abstract: The conviction of Ms. Ressa, a critic of President Rodrigo Duterte and his violent drug war, is the latest blow to press freedoms in the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANILA — Maria Ressa has been accused of fraud, tax evasion and receiving money from the Central Intelligence Agency. She has been arrested twice and posted bail eight times.
articles.byline: By Jason Gutierrez and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: Break the China Habit? Lobsters, Lights and Toilets Show How Hard It Is
articles.snippet: The risks of relying economically on the Asian superpower have never seemed clearer. But as the world tries to get moving again, it needs China more than ever.
articles.abstract: The risks of relying economically on the Asian superpower have never seemed clearer. But as the world tries to get moving again, it needs China more than ever.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the coronavirus pandemic amplifies longstanding concerns over the world’s economic dependence on China, many countries are trying to reduce their exposure to Beijing’s brand of business.
articles.byline: By Damien Cave, Motoko Rich and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: Police Chiefs Are Finding Job Security Is Hard to Come By
articles.snippet: Chiefs who promise reform must find a way to satisfy local officials, the police and their union, and a public that is increasingly critical of police tactics and behavior.
articles.abstract: Chiefs who promise reform must find a way to satisfy local officials, the police and their union, and a public that is increasingly critical of police tactics and behavior.
articles.lead_paragraph: Erika Shields was not your old-line, law-and-order police chief.

articles.headline: A Conspiracy Made in America May Have Been Spread by Russia
articles.snippet: The Americans who pushed a conspiracy theory the night of the Iowa caucuses have migrated to coronavirus conspiracies on Twitter, with help from a very Russia-friendly account.
articles.abstract: The Americans who pushed a conspiracy theory the night of the Iowa caucuses have migrated to coronavirus conspiracies on Twitter, with help from a very Russia-friendly account.

articles.headline: Civil Rights Law Protects Gay and Transgender Workers, Supreme Court Rules
articles.snippet: The court said the language of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, which prohibits sex discrimination, applies to discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity.
articles.abstract: The court said the language of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, which prohibits sex discrimination, applies to discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled on Monday that a landmark civil rights law protects gay and transgender workers from workplace discrimination, handing the movement for L.G.B.T. equality a long-sought and unexpected victory.

articles.headline: Syria’s Economy Collapses Even as Civil War Winds to a Close
articles.snippet: President Bashar al-Assad faces threats he cannot bomb into submission, as protests erupt over living standards and a rift opens among the ruling elite.
articles.abstract: President Bashar al-Assad faces threats he cannot bomb into submission, as protests erupt over living standards and a rift opens among the ruling elite.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — President Bashar al-Assad, who has mostly won Syria’s civil war, now faces an acute economic crisis that has impoverished his people, brought about the collapse of the currency and fueled a rare public rift in the ruling elite.
